segments.text: Need SSH keys for GitHub or a Linux
server running in the cloud? Here's the
[music] fastest and easiest way to do
it. On Windows, open command prompt or
PowerShell. If you're on Mac [music] OS
or Linux, just open a terminal. Enter
this command, sshen.
You'll get these prompts. Press enter
[music] three times and bam, keys
created. But if you want additional
protection for your private [music] key,
you have a second option. At the first
prompt, you should still press enter to
choose the default location for the
private key so other programs can
automatically [music] find it and use
it. However, at these prompts, you can
pick a password. Type the same on both
prompts. Note that nothing [music] will
be displayed on screen. That's normal.
This will encrypt your private key file,
which adds some protection. If someone
steals your [music] file, they cannot
use it without knowing the correct
password. And that's it. Job done. But
what's next? The command generated two
keys, one private key and one [music]
public key. Here you can see where
they're saved. Identification shows you
the full path to your private key file,
and public key [music] shows you the
full path to the public key file. As the
name suggests, it's the public key that
you can safely share with co-workers,
companies, [music] servers, and so on.
The file that ends with the pub
extension. Sharing the public key is
like giving people a lock they can
install on something that only your
private key can unlock. Which means that
[music] you never share the private key
with anyone. You share the lock, not the
key. Remember where the public key was
stored. Whenever you need it, open that
file in any simple text [music] editor.
Select all this text and copy it. Then
paste it wherever it's required. So the
next time you

fullText: Need SSH keys for GitHub or a Linux server running in the cloud? Here's the [music] fastest and easiest way to do it. On Windows, open command prompt or PowerShell. If you're on Mac [music] OS or Linux, just open a terminal. Enter this command, sshen. You'll get these prompts. Press enter [music] three times and bam, keys created. But if you want additional protection for your private [music] key, you have a second option. At the first prompt, you should still press enter to choose the default location for the private key so other programs can automatically [music] find it and use it. However, at these prompts, you can pick a password. Type the same on both prompts. Note that nothing [music] will be displayed on screen. That's normal. This will encrypt your private key file, which adds some protection. If someone steals your [music] file, they cannot use it without knowing the correct password. And that's it. Job done. But what's next? The command generated two keys, one private key and one [music] public key. Here you can see where they're saved. Identification shows you the full path to your private key file, and public key [music] shows you the full path to the public key file. As the name suggests, it's the public key that you can safely share with co-workers, companies, [music] servers, and so on. The file that ends with the pub extension. Sharing the public key is like giving people a lock they can install on something that only your private key can unlock. Which means that [music] you never share the private key with anyone. You share the lock, not the key. Remember where the public key was stored. Whenever you need it, open that file in any simple text [music] editor. Select all this text and copy it.
